growing.water: Moderate; keep soil evenly moist but well-drained
growing.soil: Fertile, well-draining soil with good organic matter

planting.height: Vines can grow 10-20 feet or more
planting.spacing: Plant 6-10 feet apart or near a trellis/support
planting.whenToPlant: Plant in spring after last frost
planting.depth: Plant seeds about 1/2 inch deep; cuttings planted at similar depth

careAndMaintenance.pruning: Prune in late winter or early spring to remove dead or overcrowded growth
careAndMaintenance.stakingOrSupport: Requires trellis, arbor, or fence for support
careAndMaintenance.overwintering: In colder zones, mulch heavily or grow container plants indoors during winter

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: Harvest ripe fruit when it turns deep purple and falls off naturally; flowers harvested just before fully open for medicinal use
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Pick fruit by hand; flowers and leaves harvested by cutting
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Fruit can be eaten fresh or made into jams/jellies; leaves and flowers dried for tea
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Fruit is edible and highly nutritious; leaves and flowers safe for medicinal use; roots and stems should not be consumed
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Passion fruit eaten fresh, juiced, or used in desserts and beverages

medicinal.Anxiety and Sleep Aid: Leaves and flowers traditionally used to reduce anxiety, promote calmness, and improve sleep quality via teas or tinctures.
medicinal.Sedative and Nervine: Acts as a mild sedative and nervine, helping to relieve nervous tension and insomnia.
medicinal.Pain Relief: Sometimes used to ease mild pain such as headaches and menstrual cramps.
medicinal.Digestive Support: Mild digestive aid, soothing stomach discomfort.

harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Mildly fragrant flowers contribute subtle scent to teas; also attract pollinators

ecologicalInfo.wildlifeResistance: Generally deer-resistant; may attract some herbivorous insects

funFacts: Passionflower flowers are complex and symbolic, historically inspiring the name due to religious symbolism.
Passion fruit is native to South America but widely cultivated globally.
